items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
"River levels have risen at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 10/01/25.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham, Sutton on Trent to Normanton, Low Marnham  to High Marnham, Sturton Road at Cottam Litton, Grassthorpe Road, the A1133 near Girton, the A57 at Dunham and A156 Gainsborough road.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes."

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday afternoon, 11/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but stable on the river Churn. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/01/25, particularly in Cerney Wick. The forecast is for another dry day and night. We expect river levels to remain steady and begin a slow fall over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the Lower River Cherwell. However flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue today, 10/01/2025, especially in the Lower Heyford and Thrupp areas, and those areas closest to the river in Kidlington. The forecast is for another dry day and night.  We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wreake in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Brentingby Dam river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday afternoon, 11/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are stable or dropping along the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, 10/01/25, especially in the Bourton On The Water and Newbridge areas. The forecast is for another dry day and night. We expect river levels to continue dropping slowly over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but starting to fall on the River Thames. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/01/2025, especially in the Abingdon and Culham areas.  It is forecast to remain dry today and over the weekend. We expect river levels to continue falling slowly over the coming days. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/01/2025, especially in the Islip areas. The forecast is for another dry day and night. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: On Monday we saw heavy rainfall in the River Nene catchment area. This means that the River Nene has risen leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on 11/01/25, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are low on the upper reaches of the Thame, and higher, but falling, on the downstream reaches.  Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected to continue today, 10/01/2025, especially in the Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. The forecast is for another dry day and night.  Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are falling but are currently still high due to previous rain and snowfall.  We are continually monitoring the situation and the river levels.
All areas between Ringwood and Christchurch could be affected and include all tributaries.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are rising steadily in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible  throughout the day 10/01/2025.    

This information is correct as of 15:30 on Fridy 10/01/2025. The causeway at Welney has approximately 18cm of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 35cm of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. 
The Environment Agency is liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road at Welney. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. 

The weather forecast is for no further rain for the next 5 days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself at risk. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow 11/01/2025.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River following recent heavy rain. Flooding may continue to affect locations near the Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, and Poyle Channel, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. No flooding to properties is currently expected.

River levels remain high but have been slowly falling, and have continued falling throughout today, Friday 10th January. We are monitoring the situation closely.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow morning, Saturday 11th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling at the Rodington and Walcot River gauges following recent heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.  

No significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen but are now slowly starting to fall on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 10/01/25, especially in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. The forecast for the next 24 hours is dry. River levels have peaked and are slowly falling but we expect river levels to remain high over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message:
River levels are high but beginning to fall at the Offord gauge. Flooding is possible today 10/01/25. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester may also be affected. 

The forecast is for no further rainfall in the next 5 days. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow 11/01/2025.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Central Bedfordshire, Beds Borough and Cambridgeshire from Wyboston to Brampton
items.message:
River levels are high but continue to fall at the Roxton (Tempsford) gauge. Flooding is possible today 10/01/25. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Wyboston to the south of Brampton, including Duloe Brook, Hen Brook and Fox Brook. The forecast is for no further rainfall in the next 5 days. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow 11/01/2025.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon but no further flooding is expected.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   

No significant rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences. 

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
items.message:
River levels are high but beginning to fall at Bedford. Flooding remains possible today 10/01/25. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Roxton. The forecast is for no further rainfall in the next 5 days. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow 11/01/2025.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Friday 10th January, and tomorrow, Saturday 11th January. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. It is likely that we may need to issue further flood alerts for this area over the weekend as levels remain high. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow afternoon, Saturday 11th January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The Parrett, Yeo, Isle and tributary rivers rose as a result of the heavy rain last weekend.
Water has overtopped and and flooded the surrounding low-lying moors. Melting ice could continue to affect the low-lying moors. 
Minimal rainfall is forecasted for the next three days so there is a only a small risk of further flooding this week, with this Flood Alert potentially remaining in force.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels
We are closely monitoring rainfall, river levels and the overall situation.
Refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and ice.
This message will be updated by 13:00 PM on 11/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Tewks. Upper Pound, Mythe, Haw Bridge and Sandhurst gauges river gauges following heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill.  

Observed peaks: Mythe 4.38m Tuesday night, 07/01/2025, Haw Bridge 5.15m Thursday evening, 09/01/2025, Sandhurst 3.99m Friday morning, 10/01/2025.   

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River Avon in Worcestershire

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham and Twyning.  

Observed peaks: - Evesham 3.49m Tuesday morning, 07/01/2025; Bredon 3.4m Tuesday night, 07/01/2025.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

It is forecast to remain dry today and over the weekend. We expect river levels to continue dropping over the coming days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Minimal rain is forecast for the next three days so there is a small risk of further flooding this week, with this Flood Alert potentially remaining in force.
We are closely monitoring rainfall, river levels and the overall situation.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Milford river gauge as a result of rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to continue to fall throughout today, 10/01/25. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Saturday 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
Floodwaters persist at Currymoor Reservoir following the significant rise of the River Tone caused by last weekend's heavy rainfall. The flood warning has now been removed for this area but we are closely monitoring rainfall, river levels and flood assets.
Water enters via Hookbridge spillway whilst the River level exceeds 7.45m. Cutts Road floods as the Currymoor Drain level is above 5.75m, and New Road as the Drain level is above 6.18m.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels.
Minimal rainfall is forecast from Friday, and while the catchments remain saturated, any additional rain is expected to cause only a slight increase in water levels.
Pumping operations continue at Currymoor with all available pumps. Water levels are gradually receding and the Parrett Relief Channel is running.
Refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 13:00 PM on 11/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Bewdley, Worcester, Diglis, Kempsey Yacht Club and Saxons Lode river gauges following heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.  

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains may affect the racecourse and Worcester County cricket ground.  

Observed peaks: Worcester 5.0m Tuesday afternoon 07/01/2025; Diglis 4.74m Tuesday afternoon, 07/01/2025; Kempsey Yacht Club 6.95m Tuesday afternoon 07/01/2025; Saxons Lode 5.10m Wednesday early morning, 08/01/2025; Bewdley 3.7m Wednesday night, 08/01/2025. 

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Observed peak: Kempsey Yacht Club 6.95m Tuesday afternoon, 07/01/2025.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message: River levels remain high at the Willington and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall and snow. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday 12/01/25. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels are high but falling at the Mythe Bridge river gauge following heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury.  

Observed peaks:- Mythe 4.38m Tuesday night, 07/01/2025; Upper Pound 4.4m Tuesday night, 07/01/2025.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid contact with flood water and move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Apperley and The Leigh
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Haw Bridge river gauge following heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect Gabb Lane at Apperley and local caravan parks.  

Observed peak at Haw Bridge 5.15m Thursday evening, 09/01/25.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for several days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.  

Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn
items.message:
River levels are high but falling at the Saxons Lode river gauge following heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding of property remains. We expect flooding to affect property at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn. Hanley Road Closes.  

Observed peak:- Saxons Lode 5.10m Wednesday early morning, 08/01/2025.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Chaceley and Haw Bridge
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Haw Bridge river gauge following heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property and roads is possible. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Tirley, Chaceley and Haw Bridge, including the B4213 Church Road.  

Observed peak: Haw Bridge 5.15m Thursday evening, 09/01/25.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for several days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  

Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Abbots Court, Deerhurst
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Haw Bridge river gauge following heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect Abbots Court, Deerhurst.  

Observed peak: Haw Bridge 5.15m Thursday evening, 09/01/25.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for several days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  

Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Witham has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Avon at Strensham and Bredon
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Bredon river gauge following heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads around Mill Lane, Strensham. Observed peaks:- 3.49m Tuesday morning, 07/01/25. Bredon 3.40m Tuesday night, 07/01/25. 

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.  

Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
River Idle in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
"This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast. 
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  Standing water may still remain and in places this may have frozen and present a hazard to drivens and pedestrians"

items.description: River Trent in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels continue to fall at the Clifton Bridge and Colwick river gauges following recent high river levels. Whilst flooding is expected to continue, this risk is reducing as the River Trent levels fall.  Areas most at risk are Thrumpton, Stoke Bardolph, Fiskerton, Hoveringham and Gunthorpe, Wykes Lane at Farndon, Tolney Lane and Kelham Road at Newark, the A6097 at Gunthorpe, Fosse Road at East-Stoke, Boat Lane at Bleasby and Hoveringham, and cellars of low-lying properties at Cavendish Bridge.   
No further rainfall is forecast.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. It is likely that standing water will remain in the floodplain and on highways. This may be frozen in places and present additional hazards to drivers and pedestrians.   
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 12:00 tomorrow, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Burton Trent
Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen but are now falling on the Loddon following a period of sustained rainfall. Flooding of some roads and low lying land adjacent to the river is expected to continue today, 10/01/25, especially in the Loddon Drive area of Wargrave, with flooding of roads affecting access to properties. The next 24 hours are forecast to be dry. River levels have peaked and we expect them to slowly fall over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at Britford, Salisbury
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though there may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

Residual surface water and groundwater may cause the levels to rise again over time. A groundwater flood alert remains in place. We will continually monitor the situation and will re-issue further warnings if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

items.description: Holderness Drain

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: Winestead Drain, Holderness Drain, Burstwick Drain, Skeffling Drain, Long Bank Drain, Keyingham Drain, Old Fleet Drain, Kellwell Stream, Lambwath Stream

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include the Holderness Drain area, including Leven and Bransholme. No further significant rainfall has been forecasted. We are closely monitoring the situation. Levels may fluctuate in response to the effects of the tide and our pumping operations, which are being operated to manage levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9pm on Friday 10//01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area (Lower Tone and Parrett Moors), so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. 
Minimal rainfall is forecast over the next three days but no further flooding is expected.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away, for example, Cutts Road.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels
Pumping operations continue at Currymoor with all available pumps. While water levels are gradually receding, the pace of reduction is slower than anticipated. River Parrett levels are being managed using the Parrett relief channel.
Refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Thames but have peaked and are slowly falling, as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 10/01/25, especially in the Shiplake area. The next 24 hours are forecast to be dry. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Avon at Twyning
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Bredon river gauge following heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads around Twyning Green.  

Observed peak:- Bredon 3.4m Tuesday afternoon, 07/01/25.  

No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water. 

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Mapledurham to Sonning
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are stabilising. However, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/01/2025, especially in the Sonning area.  It is forecast to remain dry today and over the weekend. We expect river levels to fall gradually over the coming days. We are monitoring the situation. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Pangbourne to Purley

The flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 10/01/2025, especially in the Pangbourne and Purley areas. It is forecast to remain dry today and over the weekend. We expect river levels to start falling over the coming 24 hours.  
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Datchet to Shepperton Green
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen but are now slowly falling on the River Thames as a result of a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 10/01/25, especially in the Penton Hook, Chertsey, and Egham areas. The next 24 hours are forecast to be dry. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar at Sandown remains high but is falling slowly (by 0.5cm per hour) as a result of drier weather over the last 24 hours. Minor flooding to Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road, Sandown, will continue throughout today (Friday 10/01/25). Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will still struggle to drain over the next 24 hours. At Alverstone, very minor flood impacts may continue as the river level returns to normal. The weather for the next 5 days is forecast to be mostly dry, giving the river a chance to recover. We have checked that the Bembridge sluice is operating normally. Please ensure any products used to protect gardens from flooding are operating. This Flood Alert will be removed by 12:00 on Saturday 11/01/2025.

items.description: Areas close to the River Great Ouse at Wyboston, Eaton Socon, Eynesbury, Eaton Ford, and St Neots
items.message:
River levels are high but continue to fall at the Roxton (Tempsford) gauge. Flooding reamins possible today, 10/01/2025. Areas most at risk are Wyboston Lakes, School Lane in Eaton Socon, Hardwick Road and Springbrook in Eynesbury, The Paddock and Crosshall Road in Eaton Ford and River Terrace, Priory Lane, Chandlers Wharf, Brook Street, Church Street and Browns Square in St Neots. 

The weather forecast is for no significant rainfall over the next 5 days, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal soon. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We will continue to monitor the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow 11/01/2025.

items.description: Colne Brook at Iver and Colnbrook

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next five days.

River levels are now falling steadily at the Farlows Bridge gauge. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in danger.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high and are expected to respond to recent rainfall, levels are likely to respond from the 8th of January onwards. Levels are very reactive to further rainfall. 

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 14/1/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still high but stable on the River Coln. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 10/01/25, particularly in the Fossebridge area. The forecast is for another dry day and night. We expect river levels to start to fall slowly later today. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 11/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include low-lying land and footpaths near the River Foulness and Market Weighton Canal and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. This message will be updated by 9pm on Friday 10/01/2025, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Derwent at Buttercrambe Mill
items.message: This warning has been removed due to levels falling back below levels of concern. Outlook for the next few days is for dry and cold weather. We will continue to closely monitor the situation and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Barlings Eau and Duckpool Catchwater
items.message: The risk of flooding from the Barlings Eau and Duckpool Catchwater has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Lower River Witham
items.message: On Monday, we saw heavy rainfall in the Lower Witham catchment area. This means that the River Witham has risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. No further rain is forecast for the next few days, however we expect the river to remain high and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is possible and therefore flood warnings have been issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on 11/01/25, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include the Upper Hull area including Kilham, Nafferton, Driffield, Bainton, North Dalton, Leconfield, Leven, Brandesburton, North Frodingham and Beeford. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. This message will be updated by 9pm on Friday 10/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lincoln Watercourses

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Witham, Sincil Dyke, Great Gowts Drain, Fos

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Witham has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again in response to rainfall over the last week. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 14/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently slowly falling at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the coming weeks if levels begin rising again.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again in response to rainfall over the last week. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 14/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and rising. In the last week, over half a months rain (69mm) has been recorded at Bishops Sutton. During this time, the level at Preston Candover has risen by 30cm. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, a small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding. Septic tanks in Old Alresford will be struggling to operate effectively. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday 08/01/2025 and Friday 10/01/2025, with up to 15mm expected on each day. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising slowly for around 2 weeks in response to this rain. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 14/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. This rise is from levels which were already high from the previous Winter. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising very slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton following rainfall over recent weeks.

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue rising slowly over the coming week and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme and Burshill due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected around low-lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment. No significant rainfall is forecast in the next few days.  Levels may fluctuate in response to the effects of the tide and our pumping operations, which are being operated to manage levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low Barlings and the Short Ferry area

floodArea.riverOrSea: Barlings Eau, Stainfield Beck, Marsh Drain

items.message: The River Witham has been falling steadily today Friday 10th January and we do not expect any further flooding to properties in the Barlings Eau and Short Ferry area. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: On Monday we saw heavy rainfall in the Lower Witham catchment area. This means that the Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston have risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the rivers. No further rain is forecast for the next few days, however we expect the rivers to remain high and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on 11/01/25, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries of the lower River Witham from Blankney to Sleaford

floodArea.riverOrSea: Kyme Eau, River Slea, Billinghay Skirth, Ruskington Beck, Old River Slea and Leasingham Beck

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Witham has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and rising. In the last 3 days, over half a months rain (46mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level has increased by 0.5m. From Tuesday (07/01/2025), cellar flooding is expected at the southern end of the village at South End Close and the Dolphin Pub. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday (08/01/2025) and Friday (10/01/2025), with up to 35mm of rain possible across this period. Groundwater levels are expected to rise for around 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables from cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 13/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and rising. In the last 3 days, over half a months rain (39mm) has been recorded at Andover. At Clanville Gate the rate of rise is fast at 11cm per day. From Tuesday (07/01/2025), it is possible that a small number of cellars may be affected in Appleshaw. Groundwater is affecting the sewer network at Penton Mewsey and the main road at Penton Grafton is flooded. Groundwater will emerge in many of the ditches and roads in most villages. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday (08/01/2025) and Friday (10/01/2025), with up to 35mm of rain possible across this period. Groundwater levels are expected to rise for around 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables from cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 13/01/2025.

items.description: Wider area of the South Forty Foot Drain

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Forty Foot Drain and tributaries

items.message: The risk of flooding from the South Forty Foot Drain has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Holderness Drain at Routh and Meaux
items.message: This warning has been removed due to levels falling back below levels of concern. Outlook for the next few days is for dry and cold weather. We will continue to closely monitor the situation and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Holderness Drain at Wawne Common and Woody Carr

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull

items.message: River levels remain high on Holderness Drain due to recent heavy rain. Flooding is expected to be affecting locations near Holderness Drain, particularly around isolated properties at Wawne Common, Woody Carr, and North's Bridge. Levels may fluctuate in response to the effects of the tide and our pumping operations, which are being operated to manage levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 11/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wreake at Melton Mowbray
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.   
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
No further rainfall is forecast. A controlled, steady release is currently underway at Brentingby Reservoir to restore flood storage capacity. We are closely monitoring the situation.
If you have suffered internal flood damage, take photographs and contact your insurance company. To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Witham and associated Fens from Woodhall Spa to Chapel Hill
items.message: The River Witham has been falling steadily today Friday 10th January and we do not expect any further flooding to properties between Woodhall Spa and Chapel Hill. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

items.description: River Witham and associated Fens from Chapel Hill to Boston
items.message: The River Witham has been falling steadily today Friday 10th January and we do not expect any further flooding to properties between Chapel Hill to Boston. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

items.description: River Trent at Lenton for Nottingham Park and Ride Site at Queens Drive
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed. 
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land. No further rainfall is forecast. 
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Trent at Girton
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Carlton-on-Trent and Torksey river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of property flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are access roads and properties in Girton. As levels continue to rise, the A1133 and High Street may flood, which could isolate the village.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 11/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.  
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 21:00, 10/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage
items.message:
River levels remain high but remain steady at the Carlton-on-Trent river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property is expected to continue. Areas most at risk are Carlton on Trent including Beck Cottage.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 11/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.  
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 21:00, 10/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Collingham
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently, flooding of property is expected to continue.  Areas most at risk are Collingham.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 11/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.  
Please move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and avoid contact with flood water.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 21:00, 10/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Fossdyke Canal
items.message: We are still seeing impact of heavy rainfall earlier in the week  in the Fossdyke Canal area. This means the River Trent and Fossdyke Canal remains very high, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. No further rain is forecast for the next few days, however we expect the river to remain high and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings aren't expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 11/01/2025, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Roam Drain and River Hull at Hempholme
items.message: Levels remain high on Roam Drain following recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include properties in Hempholme and around Hunt Hill Farm. Although no significant rainfall is expected in the next few days, levels remain high and flooding of properties is possible. Levels may fluctuate in response to the effects of the tide and our pumping operations, which are being operated to manage levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9pm on Friday 10//01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Dunham-on-Trent
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels. Consequently, the risk of flooding continues. Areas most at risk are the A57 Dunham Road Bridge at Dunham-on-Trent. Dunham Bridge is likely to become impassable to traffic. Property is not expected to flood at this stage.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 11/01/2025.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 21:00, 10/01/2025, or as the situation changes.
